summary: lethal complications include haemorrhage, retropharyngeal abscess and disseminated sepsis. the child was diagnosed with acute tonsillitis 2 days prior to her collapse. there were no signs of upper or lower airway obstruction. edema may play a more significant role in asphyxial unexpected deaths in cases of tonsillar hypertrophy than previously suspected. this focusses the importance of careful examination of the epiglottis and proximal laryngeal mucosa.
